dt.t: selfishness that had a {wi}gloss{/wi} of humanitarianism about it

dt: {bc}a viscous usually tinted cosmetic preparation used for adding shine and usually color to the lips {bc}{sx|lip gloss||}

et: akin to Middle High German {it}glosen{/it} to glow, shine; akin to Old English {it}geolu{/it} yellow
shortdef: a surface luster or brightness : shine

dt: {bc}to mask the true nature of {bc}give a deceptively attractive appearance to

dt.t: the misery was general, where not {wi}glossed{/wi} over by liberal application of alcohol

dt: {bc}to deal with (a subject or problem) too lightly or not at all

dt.t: {wi}glosses{/wi} over scholarly controversies rather than confronting them head-on

shortdef: to mask the true nature of : give a deceptively attractive appearance to —used with over
to deal with (a subject or problem) too lightly or not at all —used with over

dt: {bc}a brief explanation (as in the margin or between the lines of a text) of a difficult or obscure word or expression
{bc}a false and often willfully misleading interpretation (as of a text)

et: alteration (by conformation to its Latin and Greek source) of {it}glose, gloze,{/it} going back to Middle English {it}glose,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French, borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}glōsa, glōssa{/it} "tongue, language, commentary on a word or passage, compilation of such commentaries" (Latin, "collection of unfamiliar words"), borrowed from Greek {it}glôssa,{/it} (Attic) {it}glôtta,{/it} (Ionic) {it}glássa{/it} "tongue, language, obscure word requiring explanation," derivative in {it}*-i̯ā{/it} from the stem of a presumed root noun {it}*glṓks{/it} "point, something pointed," perhaps going back to an Indo-European nominative {it}*glōgh-s,{/it} genitive {it}*gl̥gh-ós{/it}; from the same base Greek {it}glôches{/it} "awns of a head of grain," {it}glōchī́s{/it} "projecting point (as the end of a yoke fastening or the barb of an arrow)"

Despite its Indo-European look, this set of Greek words has no definite congeners in other Indo-European languages; kinship with Slavic {it}*glogŭ{/it} "hawthorn" (Czech {it}hloh,{/it} Polish {it}głóg,{/it} Serbian & Croatian {it}glȍg{/it}; Russian {it}glog{/it} "dogwood") is uncertain.
shortdef: a brief explanation (as in the margin or between the lines of a text) of a difficult or obscure word or expression
a false and often willfully misleading interpretation (as of a text)

dt: {bc}to dispose of by false or perverse interpretation

dt.t: trying to {wi}gloss{/wi} away the irrationalities of the universe

et: alteration (after {et_link|gloss:3|gloss:3}) of {it}glose, gloze,{/it} going back to Middle English {it}glosen,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}gloser,{/it} borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}glōsāre, glōssāre,{/it} verbal derivative of {it}glōsa, glōssa{/it} "commentary on a word or passage, compilation of such commentaries" {ma}{mat|gloss:3|}{/ma}
shortdef: to provide a gloss for : explain, define
to dispose of by false or perverse interpretation

et: borrowed from Greek {it}glōsso-,{/it} combining form from {it}glôssa{/it} "tongue, language" {ma}{mat|gloss:3|}{/ma}

dt: {bc}to treat or describe (something, such as a serious problem or error) as if it were not important

dt.t: The problems were ignored or {it}glossed over{/it}.

shortdef: to treat or describe (something, such as a serious problem or error) as if it were not important

dt: {bc}a viscous usually tinted cosmetic preparation used for adding shine and usually color to the lips {bc}{sx|gloss:1||3}

dt.t: … the minimalist look of a little mascara, glowing cheeks and {wi}lip gloss{/wi} …

shortdef: a viscous usually tinted cosmetic preparation used for adding shine and usually color to the lips : gloss
